title: 110_hr3148
content: The "Child Pornography Elimination Act of 2007" mandates a minimum sentence of 2 to 15 years for possession of child pornography. Section 13032 of Title 42, United States Code, is strengthened to ensure effective reporting of child pornography. Section 227(b)(2) of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to impose fines for providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services who knowingly or negligently fail to report child abuse, with varying penalties for initial and subsequent failures. The Federal Communications Commission can impose civil penalties for failure to report child abuse by electronic communication service providers, with fines up to $50,000 for initial violations and up to $100,000 for subsequent violations. The FCC has the authority to enforce these penalties and will establish regulations in consultation with the Attorney General. SEC. 4 amends Section 2252(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly accessing child pornography with intent to view. SEC. 5 adds a conspiracy provision for Chapter 77 offenses. SEC. 6 mandates restitution for certain child sex offenses. Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory restitution for offenses. The court must order the defendant to pay the victim's full losses, including medical expenses, in addition to any other penalties. Restitution orders will be enforced similarly to other orders under section 3663A. The court must order mandatory restitution for offenses, including medical expenses, therapy, lost income, attorney's fees, and other losses incurred by the victim as a result of the offense. The issuance of a restitution order is mandatory and cannot be declined based on economic circumstances. The court must order mandatory restitution for offenses, including medical expenses, therapy, lost income, attorney's fees, and other losses incurred by the victim as a result of the offense. Restitution may not be declined based on economic circumstances or if the victim has received compensation from insurance or other sources. The term 'victim' includes individuals harmed by a crime, with provisions for minors, incapacitated individuals, and legal guardians. SEC. 7 amends the definition of illicit sexual conduct to include the production of child pornography. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute by amending various sections of title 18, United States Code to include section 1591. This includes amendments related to sexual exploitation, pornography, repeat offenders, release and detention, and administrative subpoenas.
